node.bodyText:
@fdkong @cticenhour
I have an issue configuring petsc. The log below was generated by invoking ./configure without args in the moose/petsc/ submodule.
Posting here so we can easily share the large configure.log generated with ./configure

node.title: Does moose currently support quasi Newton?
node.bodyText:
Hello, everyone.
I wonder if moose supports quasi Newton.  I tried to set the -snes_type to qn, but it doesn't seem right. I am not familiar with petsc. Is there any other option I need to set? Thank you very much for any help.
@fdkong

QN seems to be working. But one thing I would like to point out:  if Newton/PJFNK can not converge on your problem, I would not expect QN have a better convergence. QN is trying to figure out a "cheap" way to compute Jacobian based on the solution/matrix of the previous  iteration. It might not be as accurate as the one calculated at the current step.
In other words, if you see something like " Solve Did NOT Converge!", you should not be surprised.

node.title: numerical simulation shock induced cavitation
node.bodyText:
Hello Everyone
I am new to moose. I am used to OpenFOAM for hydrodynamics cavitation simulation. I am wondering whether I can use MOOSE to simulate the rarefaction behind shock wave induced cavitation. I suppose the phase filed method is required. some pressure–volumetric strain relation can be adopted for the phase field model.  to capture the shock, I need compressible navier stokes. the viscosity could be neglected.  is there any suggestion ?

Hello
You would be welcome to develop this capability in MOOSE. Either:

off of the compressible finite volume formulations (Kurdanov-Tadmor or HLLC) in the Navier Stokes module. We have not built the link to phase field for this either, I think you would want to re-implement phase field with finite volume OR increase our capabilities for finite volume/finite element coupling.
by adding a fully compressible scheme in finite element in the Navier Stokes module. Then you could could couple to phase field more easily.

Guillaume

node.title: Inquiry about chemical potential value in BC in 2D CH model
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have some questions about how to set the chemical potential in CH model in Boundary condition. For concentration at boundary, it is simple, we only need to set the concentration we want at the boundary. However, for chemical potential, I was wondering what chemical potential expression in CH model is? What value should we set for the chemical potential at each boundary?
Anyone have any suggestions?
Thank you very much.
Best regards,

Sorry for the slow reply on this. If you use the split Cahn-Hilliard formulation, where we solve for the chemical potential and concentration as two coupled variables, then chemical potential is one of your nonlinear variables and you can use any of the BC classes to set it as you like. We generally recommend the split CH formulation instead of the direct solution method because you get better numerical performance. More info about the differences can be found here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/phase_field/Phase_Field_Equations.html

node.title: Question about calculating the velocity of the moving interface in 2D CH model
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I have some questions about calculating the velocity.
Is there any postprocessors that can be used to calculate the velocity of the the moving interface in a 2D CH model? Do I need to track the boundary's location at each time step and then calculate the velocity by myself? Or there is one commands that can directly calculate the velocity?
Thank you very much.
Best regards.

Hi there- can you tell a little more about the geometry of your problem? If you know exactly where on the interface you want to calculate velocity, you could use the FindValueOnLine postprocessor to determine the position of the interface at each time step, then take the difference in position between two time steps and divide by dt (which you can get from csv output of all postprocessor data). It will be a little more tricky if you want to know the velocity of the interface at each position, so please let us know what geometry you want to consider.

node.title: Spherical coordinates
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
This is my first message here and I'm new in MOOSE so I'd like to say I'm glad to join this community!
I have a model where my mesh is in one dimension and I'm using the default cartesian coordinates. This runs well and converges very fast (1 minute).
My goal is to run the same thing in one dimension but by using spherical (and also cylindrical) coordinates so I simulate a 3D (or 2D) with it. So I added a block [Problem] in my input file and specifies coord-type=RSPHERICAL (or RZ).
And nothing converges anymore. How does this actually work and would you have any suggestion to make this converge?
I have mesh adaptivity (uniform-refine=3) and also a time step adaptivity (with the tilmestep that can go until 10^-10, ...)
Thanks a lot for your help :)

Hello
Switching to RSPHERICAL adapts the size of the elements in the background and also changes the definitions of common vector operators (grad etc) for that coordinate system.
RSPHERICAL with R=0 can be challenging for some physics. Can you please quickly try to offset it by a little bit, translating the system to start at R=0.01 for example.
Guillaume

node.title: Raspberry Pi Cluster Docker Swarm
node.bodyText:
Hey everyone,
I recently started working on a side project trying to figure out how to run MOOSE simulations on a cluster of Raspberry Pis. I got my inspiration for this from LANL's 750 node Raspberry Pi cluster. Anyway, I am currently trying to use Docker Swarm to handle the load balancing between the nodes, but I am stuck on not being able to deploy the container as a swarm service. Has anyone done this before or have advice on how to proceed? More details below
Step 1
Build docker image of MOOSE specifically for arm v7. Docker hub link below, I have been able to run this on a single raspberry pi without issues. The operating system is Raspberry Pi OS Lite.
https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/ats5662/moose_armv7_docker_image
Step 2
Create swarm on 4 node Raspberry Pi cluster
sudo docker swarm init --advertise-addr <node 1 IP address> # run on node 1
sudo docker swarm join-token manager # add another manager
sudo docker swarm join <manager token> # add node 2 as manager
sudo docker swarm join <worker token> # add node 3 as worker
sudo docker swarm join <worker token> # add node 4 as worker
sudo docker node ls # check node list
Step 3
Pull docker image on node 1
sudo docker pull ats5662/moose_armv7_docker_image
Step 4
Create docker service
sudo docker service create --name MOOSE  ats5662/moose_armv7_docker_image
I am getting the following error/output - this will loop until I stop it
overall progress: 0 out of 1 tasks
1/1: preparing [=================================>                 ]
verify: Detected task failure --> Fail
I am not sure what's wrong because the error message doesn't provide helpful info. If anyone has suggestions on what to do next, it would be greatly appreciated. I am new to docker and docker swarm, so if I am making any rookie mistakes or have a misunderstanding, I apologize. Let me know if additional info is needed. Thanks!
@loganharbour knows about the docker build a lot too

This seems more like a docker-not-giving-you-any-useful-information issue. Take a look at https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53222530/getting-detected-task-failure-for-some-images-while-creating-docker-service; looks like you should be able to get more info from the logs?

Thank you for this information. I ended up dropping the docker swarm approach in favor of the Slurm Workload Manager & openMPI. I think many real HPCs use similar programs?
These three articles do a pretty good job showing most of the setup process
Part 1: https://glmdev.medium.com/building-a-raspberry-pi-cluster-784f0df9afbd
Part 2: https://glmdev.medium.com/building-a-raspberry-pi-cluster-aaa8d1f3d2ca
Part 3: https://glmdev.medium.com/building-a-raspberry-pi-cluster-f5f2446702e8
Job submission: https://hprc.tamu.edu/files/training/2021/Fall/Slurm_Job_Scheduling_2021_fall.pdf
I haven't fully tested it out yet, but hopefully will in the coming weeks after school gets out for the summer.

node.title: BarrierFunctionMaterial with coefficients
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I am in the process of learning MOOSE, but I have a question.
Using MOOSE BarrierFunctionMaterial with g_order high, (g(η) = η^2(1−η ^2) ^2). Is it possible, in a straightforward way, to add coefficients in front of the η-term, where one of the terms needs to be space-depended?
All help and explanation are very much appreciated.
Best regards
Karl

Hello
I looked at the parameters and it doesnt look like it.
I suggest you use a ParsedMaterial to add this prefactor:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer. If I’ve understood correctly, then I can define it as I’ve done it below, I just need to rewrite the math function into a MOOSE function? But how do I define spatial dependence of the order parameter that looks like:  g/2(∇η)^2 as a coefficient?
[./f_eta]
  type = ParsedMaterial
  f_name = f_eta # the name of the function
  args = 'alpha beta gamma' # here is where a define the coefficients
  function =  Ft[η] = ∫[ g/2(∇η)^2 + (α/2)η^2 + (β/4)η^4+ (γ/6)η^6 ]dr

  outputs = exodus
[../]

I apologize if my questions are somewhat strange or trivial, but I’m very new to MOOSE, but excited to learn.
Thanks again for all the help.

Hello
Please see the discussion in this post for how to get gradients of material properties.
#20628
Basically you will have to propagate derivatives, starting from the gradients of the primary variables.
Then once you have defined a gradient of a material property you can use it in a ParsedMaterial as part of the prefactor
Guillaume
